_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Railyard handles their own Emergency Response activities/training, including a work alone procedure.
_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Training provided to railyard employees, computer based trainings annual and classroom every three years.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Railcars are visually inspected as needed through secutirrounds and/or security cameras

_emerg_resp.LEPCCoordinationReason: Not under CF's operational control - any coordination with LEPC will be completed by Watco
_emerg_resp.LocalResponseAgencyCoordinationReason: Not under CF's operational control - any coordination with LEPC will be completed by Watco

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Program (RMP) Executive Summary
CF Industries Sales, LLC - Forebay, ID Railyard

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:
Operating in a safe and responsible manner is a core value and an integral part of CF Industries. Our safety strategy revolves around our "Do It Right" value and permeates our business in three key ways:
-	Robust systems that provide a clear, repeatable direction toward excellence.
-	Superior performance that aligns effective and efficient EHS activities with operations.
-	Engaged culture that empowers consistent behaviors that drive toward excellence.
CF Industries works closely with emergency responders and other local officials to develop detailed emergency response plans that extend beyond our physical operating locations.

Forebay Railyard and the regulated substances handled:
The Forebay Railyard stores and distributes anhydrous ammonia. The regulated substances, as defined by 40 CFR Part 68, which are present at the facility in more than the threshold quantity are anhydrous ammonia.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
The Forebay Railyard has taken all the necessary steps to comply with all of the accidental release and chemical-specific prevention requirements as set forth in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR Part 68. While this facility is not subject to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119 because it is considered a "normally unoccupied remote facility" per 1910.119(a)(2), we are following many of the requirements as a best practice. The following summarizes the elements of the release and chemical-specific prevention that are in place at our facility:
-	Process safety information that is accurate and up to date;
-	Well-trained operating, maintenance, and contract personnel;
-	Written operating procedures;
-	Mechanical integrity procedures for proce

oyees are required to have depending on their responsibilities. Furthermore, the plan commits the company's management team to devote the necessary resources to prepare, implement and audit the ERP.

Planned changes to improve safety:
Rigorous training, drills, audits, cooperation with emergency responders and local officials, recognition programs and participation in industry safety initiatives help keep our focus on what it takes to "Do It Right." Through our ongoing commitment to make our facility as safe as possible for employees, contractors, the community, and the environment, we are always continuously improving our systems and practices.
